latestVersion.specialPermissions: Additional special permissions, where applicable, are described in the restrictions field.
latestVersion.restrictions: As explained in the ICPSR Processing Note in the codebook, variables respid (respondent ID), dm4 (year of birth), dm17 (race if Hispanic or Latino, dm18 (race if not Hispanic or Latino), and dm1718 (combined responses to dm17 and dm18) are restricted from general dissemination for reasons of confidentiality. Users interested in obtaining these data must complete an Agreement for the Use of Confidential Data, specify the reasons for the request, and obtain IRB approval or notice of exemption for their research. Apply for access to these data through the ICPSR restricted data contract portal, which can be accessed via the study home page http://dx.doi.org/10.3886/ICPSR30421.v1 .
latestVersion.conditions: AVAILABLE. This study is freely available to the general public.
latestVersion.disclaimer: The original collector of the data, ICPSR, 		and the relevant funding agency bear no responsibility 		for use of the data or for interpretations or inferences 		based upon such uses.

fields.value: Associated Press Poll on the Health Care Overhaul, by Stanford University With the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, October-November 2009 [United States]

dsDescriptionValue.value:
This poll was intended to measure public opinion about the proposed health care overhaul that was being considered by the United States Congress while the survey was in the field. It measured support and opposition to certain general goals for the overhaul, as well as support and opposition to
specific policy proposals. Other topics investigated by the survey include health status, health insurance status, health care system experience, general perceptions of the health care system, political ideology, and approval/disapproval of the Obama Administration's performance.  Demographic characteristics covered by the survey include marital status, employment status, year of birth, home tenure, religion, religiosity, race, Hispanic origin, and income.

topicClassValue.value: HMCA II. Cost/Access to Health Care
ICPSR IX. Health Care and Health Facilities

distributorAffiliation.value: Institute for Social Research, University of Michigan

value: Adults aged 18 years or older in the United States, including Alaska and Hawaii.

fields.value: Nationally-representative probability sample of adults in the United States. The interviews were conducted in English and Spanish on both landline and cellular telephones.

The data contain a weight variable that accounts for probabilities of selection, as well as age, sex, education, and race, using targets from the March 2008 supplement of the Current Population Survey. In addition to these factors, the weighting takes into account the patterns of land and cell phone usage by region from the 2008 Spring estimates provided by Mediamark Research, Inc.
Checked for undocumented or out-of-range codes.
